Description: Glazed composition amulet in the form of the double-sided profile of a red crown, designed with incisions and pierced at the top for suspension. The glaze is light brown with reddish patches.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Tell Dafana, North-west Ptolemaic mound ? (?)
Curator's comments: Provenance not mentioned in the Museum register, but probably from Tell Dafana, according to the context of the item in the list, and similarity of material with other amulets surely from the site. Probably one of the 5 "lower crowns" described among the "glazed pottery amulets of late work, probably late Ptolemaic", coming from the North-West Mound, mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p.79 § 79. Probably matching with EA 18642.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p.79 § 79) (?)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.40, p.45, p.60-61, p.180, pl.22)
